Award.AwardTitle: KanSec: the Greater Kansas Area Security Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Greater Kansas Area Security Workshop (KanSec) provides a regular forum for researchers and students across Kansas and the neighboring states to present research and educational activities in the field of cybersecurity, and to promote interactions and collaborations. With three NSA/DHS National Centers of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education (CAE/IAE) and IA Research (CAE/R) in the State of Kansas, substantial cybersecurity research and educational activities are taking place. KanSec was formed to encourage collaboration despite the geographical remoteness of the area. The first two KanSec workshops, in Spring and Fall 2012 respectively, included over 50 participants each, with about 10 student presentations at each event. The next workshop is scheduled to be hosted at the University of Kansas in the Spring of 2013, and has received inquiries about participation from universities in neighboring states including Oklahoma, Nebraska, and Arkansas. To improve the quality of the workshop and to give students better experiences, KanSec will invite renowned researchers as keynote speakers for future KanSec workshops.

This grant supports student travel to the KanSec workshops in spring and fall 2013.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Kansas received $16,000 to provide travel grants for students attending KanSec: The Greater Kansas Area Security Workshop. The workshop is a semi-annual event that brings together researchers and practitioners in security- and networking-related fields across the central area of the US. The KanSec workshop was renamed to Central Area Networking and Security Workshop (CANSec) in April 2014, to reflect the deep involvement of the networking community as well as the geographical expansion of the KanSec community.

The NSF travel grant is intended to support students attending KanSec/CANSec workshops in 2013 and 2014. A total of 86 student-trips were supported by the grant. In particular, 18 students were supported in KanSec III, 13 students were supported in KanSec IV, 29 students were supported in CANSec V, and 26 students were supported in CANSec VI. Among the awardees, 39 were oral or poster presenters, 11 were Ph.D. forum presenters, 19 were cyber defense competition participants or volunteers. Students from 11 different institutions in Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Colorado, Nebraska, and Arkansas were supported.

With the help of the travel grant, students got the chance to attend the workshop, listen to keynote talks and panels, present their own achievements, and meet with researchers. This is a great opportunity for them to build up their own social networks, and succeed in their future career. In all four workshops, the organizing committees secured external funding to support keynote speakers. Meanwhile, stimulated by the NSF award, the workshop organizers also attracted financial supports from Emerging Threats, BATS Global Markets, Inc., as well as the host institutions.

Industrial panels and industrial-academia joint panels were added to the workshop since KanSec IV, to expose students to the opinions of security practitioners and industrial researchers, and to connect academic researchers with industrial partners and to initiate opportunities for collaboration. Ph.D. forums were added to the workshop since CANSec V, for presentations of work-in-progress from Ph.D. students. In CANSec VI, the first CANSec cyber-defense competition was organized, to provide students with a platform to apply theoretical knowledge into practice, and to obtain hands-on cyber security experiences.

With the expansion of the CANSec community, more universities become interested in hosting future CANSec workshops. By June 2015, the steering committee received commitments to host the workshops in fall of 2015, spring of 2016 and fall of 2016.
